com.spotify.sdk.android

Class Spotify

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.spotify.sdk.android.Spotify

  • public class Spotify
extends Object
    The main "entry point" to the Spotify Android SDK. Use it to create and destroy the Player object. The class ensures that only one instance of Player is created.

    • Method Detail

      • getPlayer

        public Player getPlayer(Config config,
                        Object reference,
                        Player.InitializationObserver observer)
        Get (or possibly create) an instance of the player.
        If you have multiple fragments which all want their own player, you should take care to make sure that only one thread calls this to initialize the player.
        SUPER IMPORTANT: you must call destroyPlayer(Object) when you are finished using the Player, otherwise native resources will be leaked.
        Parameters:
        config - Configuration object for the player.
        reference - Object which owns this player. This same object must be passed to destroyPlayer(Object).
        observer - Observer to be notified when initialization is complete. In the event that the player has already been initialized, then Player.InitializationObserver.onInitialized() will be called directly.
        Returns:
        Initialized Player instance

      • setPlayer

        public void setPlayer(Player player)
        Injects a Player instance to be returned when getPlayer(com.spotify.sdk.android.playback.Config, Object, com.spotify.sdk.android.playback.Player.InitializationObserver) is called. This is useful if one wants to override the Player class to control playback behavior directly. It is NOT necessary to call this method unless you wish to subclass the Player, otherwise a Player instance is created for you automatically in getPlayer().
        Parameters:
        player - Player instance
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If the global player instance is non-null. This implies that you should call this method directly after initializing the Spotify object, and before any calls to getPlayer().

      • destroyPlayer

        public static void destroyPlayer(Object reference)
        Release a player resource.
        Since there is only a single instance of the player, it is refcounted using Object instances, which must be correctly registered in the call to getPlayer(com.spotify.sdk.android.playback.Config, Object, com.spotify.sdk.android.playback.Player.InitializationObserver) The player will only be actually destroyed once the last object has released it.
        Ideally, if you are using a Player from an Activity or Fragment, you should call this method in the onDestroy() overridden method. This method is safe to call even if your Activity/Fragment exited early and never finished creating its player. Bottom line -- always call this.
        Parameters:
        reference - Object which owned this player.
